description: From Middle English þe, from Old English þē (“thee”, originally dative, but later also accusative), from Proto-Germanic *þiz (“thee”), from Proto-Indo-European *te (“second-person singular pronoun”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian die (“thee”), West Frisian dy (“thee”), German Low German di (“thee”), German dir (“thee”, dative pron.), Icelandic þér (“thee”). More at thou.

verbs.description: thee (third-person singular simple present thees, present participle theeing, simple past and past participle theed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To address (a person) using the pronoun thee.

description: From Middle English theen (“to increase, prosper, flourish”), from Old English þēon (“to thrive, prosper, flourish, grow”), from Proto-Germanic *þinhaną (“to thrive, succeed”), from Proto-Indo-European *tenk- (“to succeed, turn out well”). Cognate with Dutch gedijen (“to flourish, thrive, prosper, succeed”), German gedeihen (“to thrive”), Gothic 𐌲𐌰𐌸𐌴𐌹𐌷𐌰𐌽 (gaþeihan, “to increase, thrive”).

verbs.description: thee (third-person singular simple present thees, present participle theeing, simple past and past participle theed)

description: From Pitman zee, which it is related to phonetically and graphically, and the sound it represents.

entries.meaning: The letter ⟨(⟩, which stands for the th sound /ð/ in Pitman shorthand.

description: Respelling of the popularized by Thee Temple ov Psychick Youth.
